title: 113_hr221
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Mergers, Acquisitions, and Risky Takeovers Supplied by American Labor and Entrepreneurship Act of 2013" or the "SMART SALE Act of 2013". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines "covered entity" as any entity engaged in interstate commerce in the US that owns federally-funded technology, and "covered transaction" as any merger or acquisition that could result in control by a foreign government or citizen. The Act defines a "covered entity" as any entity engaged in interstate commerce in the US that owns federally-funded technology. A "covered transaction" is any merger or acquisition that could result in control by a foreign government or citizen. A foreign country described in the Act means any country where natural persons own more than 50% of a corporation or legal entity. The Act defines a "covered entity" as any entity engaged in interstate commerce in the US that owns federally-funded technology. A "covered transaction" is any merger or acquisition that could result in control by a foreign government or citizen. Subparagraph (A) lists countries to which certain provisions of the Act apply, including China, North Korea, state sponsors of terrorism, countries providing sanctuary to terrorist organizations, and any other country determined by the President. The President may waive the applicability of certain provisions with respect to a foreign country if it is in the national interest of the United States and a justification is provided to Congress. The term "state sponsor of terrorism" is defined as any country whose government supports terrorism. The term "terrorism" refers to any country determined by the Secretary of State to have repeatedly supported international terrorism under various provisions of law. The term "foreign terrorist organization" is defined as any organization designated by the Secretary of State under section 219 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Federal energy research and development funding includes funding for researching new energy technologies or applying existing ones in a novel manner. The term "federally-funded technology" refers to technology developed using Federal energy research and development funding, with exceptions for technologies not specified in funding documents or unforeseen at the time of funding. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENTS. A covered entity must notify the Secretary of Energy within 7 days of starting negotiations for a covered transaction. The notification should include identification of the entities involved, details of federal energy research funding received, and plans for repaying any federal agency loans. The notification required for a covered transaction includes details of federal energy research funding received and plans for repaying federal agency loans. Failure to make this notification can result in imprisonment for up to 5 years and fines as per title 18, United States Code. Additionally, Federal agencies providing energy research funding can recoup funds if necessary. Federal energy research and development funding recipients must repay all amounts if a covered transaction leads to foreign control. The Secretary of Energy must establish regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Energy must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of receiving a notification required by section 3(a). The report must include all information provided by the covered entity, an assessment of cybersecurity threats, disclosure of additional federal energy research funding, and an assessment of the transaction's impact on US interests. The Secretary of Energy must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The report should identify covered entities in covered transactions, detail government funding received by parties involved, and specify the total federal energy research funding received and scheduled to receive by the covered entity.
